column2: Home > Abbott Northwestern Hospital > Services > Virginia Piper Cancer Institute® > Programs and services > Piper Breast Center® > High Risk Program for breast cancer Abbott Northwestern Hospital Virginia Piper Cancer Institute® Piper Breast Center® Care team Services Low-cost mammography Molecular breast imaging Integrative therapies Cancer rehabilitation & lymphedema program Treatment High Risk Program Cancer Survivorship Care Plan Patient stories Video tour Subscribe to e-newsletter High Risk Program for breast cancer If you are at high risk for breast cancer, we can help. Our goal is to reduce your chance of developing cancer. We also want to provide screening that will find breast cancer in its earliest, most treatable stages if it occurs. The High Risk Program is designed for people who are concerned that they are at high risk for developing breast cancer. Our program offers a complete assessment of your breast cancer risk, individual interventions and screenings, and a plan for how to reduce risks. A team comprised of a surgeon, genetic counselor, registered nurse and other breast specialists as needed will work with you to create this plan. We will coordinate breast cancer screenings and discuss options to reduce your risk. For some patients, we’ll talk about    genetic testing as an option. If we determine genetic testing will be helpful, we’ll arrange for a formal genetic consult. We’ll make sure testing is done on the right family member and the results are reliably interpreted for you and your family. Am I at high risk for getting breast cancer? The following criteria would suggest you might benefit from an appointment in our High Risk Program. Personal history The High Risk Program for breast cancer is appropriate for people with a personal history of: a breast biopsy showing LCIS (lobular cancer in situ ) a breast biopsy showing ADH (atypical ductal hyperplasia) or ALH (atypical lobular hyperplasia) a history of radiation therapy to the chest between the ages of 10 and 30 BRCA1 or BRCA2, TP53, PTEN, or other known breast cancer gene mutation Family history The High Risk Program for breast cancer is also appropriate for people with a family history of: a close relative with breast cancer at a young age, usually younger than 45-50 a close relative with ovarian cancer two or more close relatives with breast cancer on the same side of the family, especially if diagnosed at an age younger than 60 a brother or father with breast cancer BRCA1 or BRCA2, TP53, PTEN, or other known breast cancer gene mutation Make an appointment Talk with your primary care provider. Check with your insurance company about coverage. Call 612-863-3150 to schedule an appointment. .rellinks ul li {background-image:none !important
} Related resources Genetic counseling In the news: Dr. Michaela Tsai discusses BRCA surgery on KSTP apikey = '3854eedad78f40c79297821a5a1c5e36'

Minneapolis Heart Institute® The Minneapolis Heart Institute® is recognized internationally as one of the world's leading providers of heart and vascular care. column2: Home > Abbott Northwestern Hospital > Services > Virginia Piper Cancer Institute® > Programs and services > Piper Breast Center® > Molecular breast imaging Abbott Northwestern Hospital Virginia Piper Cancer Institute® Piper Breast Center® Care team Services Low-cost mammography Molecular breast imaging Integrative therapies Cancer rehabilitation & lymphedema program Treatment High Risk Program Cancer Survivorship Care Plan Patient stories Video tour Subscribe to e-newsletter Molecular breast imaging Molecular breast imaging (MBI) is a test that may detect breast cancer. Before the images of your breast are taken, a radiology technologist will inject a small amount a radioactive fluid into an intravenous (IV) line in your arm. A special camera is used to take images that highlight cancer cells as “bright spots” inside the breast. How is MBI different from a mammogram? MBI provides a different type of information than a mammogram. It shows activity of some cancer cells that cannot be seen on a mammogram. MBI does not replace regular screening mammograms. MBI is used to help find breast cancer when more testing is needed. Who should consider a MBI? Your doctor will tell you if MBI is right for you. In general, MBI is useful for women who: are newly diagnosed with breast cancer have lumps that can be felt but are not seen with a mammogram or ultrasound are not able to have an MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) have uncertain or questionable areas on a mammogram, ultrasound or MRI have scarring from previous breast surgeries MBI exam Before the exam The appointment will last about 90 minutes. Please arrive at the Piper

column1: minutes early. You may bring a personal music player (MP3, iPod ® ) to listen to music to help you relax. You will be asked to change into a robe to wear during the exam. During the exam A mammography technologist will be with you during the exam. You will sit during the entire exam. You will have an IV line put in your arm. The radioactive fluid will be injected through the IV. Your breast will be lightly compressed for a few minutes while the images are taken. On average, images of two different views will be taken of each breast. A radiologist (doctor of X-ray) will review your images before you leave. If any more images are needed, they will be taken at that time. After the exam You may return to your normal activities. A radiologist will interpret (read) your MBI images. The results will be sent to your doctor. If you have not heard from your doctor within 3 to 5 days after your exam, please call his or her office for your results. Insurance Coverage You will need a referral from your doctor to have MBI. MBI may not be covered by all insurance providers. Please call your insurance provider to find out exactly what is and isn’t covered under your plan, and how much you have to pay yourself. You will receive two separate bills for this test. The first bill will be for having the exam done. The second bill will be for the radiologist fee for interpreting the results of this exam. Source: Allina Health's Patient Education Department Reviewed by: Allina Health's Patient Education Department First published: 04/20/2015 Last reviewed: 04/20/2015 For more information For more information or to determine if you qualify, call 612-863-3150 . apikey = '3854eedad78f40c79297821a5a1c5e36'

column2: Home > Abbott Northwestern Hospital > About us > Careers > Pharmacy Residency Program Abbott Northwestern Hospital Careers Pharmacy Residency Program Rotations Preceptors Current pharmacy residents Contact us PGY1 Pharmacy Practice Residency
column3: ASHP-accredited PGY2 Cardiology Pharmacy Residency PGY2 Pharmacy Residency in Infectious Diseases PGY2 Health System Pharmacy Administration Residency Pharmacy Residency Program The Abbott Northwestern Pharmacy Residency Program provides residents with skill development in basic and specialized patient-centered care, service excellence, practice management and leadership. Pharmacy practice is decentralized, supported by an Epic electronic health record and a medication distribution

column1: system of automated dispensing cabinets through which over 90 percent of medication doses are supplied. Residents interact with dozens of pharmacists with skills in a variety of clinical pharmacy specialties, management and leadership. Residents gain valuable experience by participating in multidisciplinary patient care rounds, medication use assessments, preparing and presenting educational programs,

staffing and completing a major research project. Residents are involved in student instruction through teaching assistant assignments at the University of Minnesota College of Pharmacy as well as precepting of APPE/IPPE students in the hospital. Abbott Northwestern retained its first place ranking for the Best Hospital in the Twin Cities and second in Minnesota in the U.S. News & World Report Best Hospital Rankings, being ranked in the top 50 in 5 medical specialties – cardiology and heart surgery, geriatrics, gynecology, orthopedics, and

neurology and neurosurgery. In 2014, the American Nurses Credentialing Center awarded continued Magnet Recognition Program® status to Abbott Northwestern Hospital, making it one of less than five percent of all U.S. hospitals that have been designated Magnet TM facilities. The hospital is home to

the Courage Kenny Rehabilitation Institute, Minneapolis Heart Institute, Penny George Institute for Health and Healing, and the Virginia Piper Cancer Institute. The hospital maintains an academic affiliation with the University of Minnesota College of Pharmacy. apikey = '3854eedad78f40c79297821a5a1c5e36'

Point of care ultrasound and research on brain aneurysms are among many donor-funded initiatives that help us develop innovative programs and advance patient care. Support from donors helps ensure that Abbott Northwestern will continue to excel as a top medical center, providing expert, compassionate care to all of its patients. Make a difference today: Give now Nursing Excellence Initiative - Priority project Recognizing the importance of nursing to the overall success of Abbott Northwestern Hospital and patient outcomes, the Abbott Northwestern Hospital Foundation has initiated a multi-year, multi-million dollar effort to ensure that the high quality nursing care that currently exists continue. We invite you to watch the video to learn more and understand why a gift in support of nurses is a thoughtful investment of your dollars. Make your gift today . Abbott Northwestern Today Stay up to date on how donations positively impact patients, their families and the community. Read and subscribe to

column1: the Foundation's Today e-newsletter. Interested in volunteering? Please visit our Volunteer page or call the Volunteer Office at  612-863-4281. By volunteering at Abbott Northwestern Hospital, you will make  a difference in people’s lives.  Volunteers from age 15 will have the  opportunity to serve patients, guests and employees. How to become a volunteer Submit an online application Adult application (18+) College student application Junior volunteer application (15 to 18 years of age) You will receive a link on how to complete the required steps to volunteer after you submit an online application: Complete independent online orientation session within two weeks of submitting online application. Complete health clearance form and screening. Once you completed steps 1 and 2, a staff member from the volunteer office will contact you with information on how to schedule your onsite onboarding shift. For more information Call 612-863-4816 or email us Current volunteers Online access to VicNet allows you to: View your schedule Sign up for additional shifts Remove scheduled shifts View messages, news and updates Update personal information Check your volunteer hours Login to VicNet apikey = '3854eedad78f40c79297821a5a1c5e36'

To discuss your particular philanthropic interests, or for more information about giving opportunities, please contact the Foundation at 612-863-4126. Richard Meyer president Richard Meyer became president of the Abbott Northwestern Hospital Foundation in 2007. Previously, he was vice president of organizational advancement for Minnesota Masonic Homes and director of the Children's Theatre Company's development program. He has a bachelor’s degree in political science from the University of Washington in Seattle and a jurisprudence degree from the University of Minnesota. Deena Bartley administrative assistant Deena Bartley joined the Foundation staff in October of 2013. She brings with her 23 years of experience in public and non-profit organizations. Most recently, she served as project and development coordinator at Search Institute in Minneapolis. She holds a BA in Sociology from Cornell College and a MA in Liberal Studies from Hamline University. Stacy Elsholtz executive assistant Stacy Elsholtz has served as the Executive Assistant to the Foundation President since 2009. Prior to joining the Foundation, she served as a fundraising professional for the Minnesota Orchestra where she supported capital campaign, major gift and planned giving efforts. She holds a bachelor's degree in music education from Bethel College. Nicki Hines senior development officer Nicki joined the Foundation in July 2015 and

column1: brings with her more than 15 years of experience in fundraising, program
development, and project management. Prior to joining the Foundation, Nicki held
corporate and foundation fundraising positions in both higher education and
social service. Nicki holds a master’s degree in organizational
leadership from St. Catherine University and an undergraduate degree in

sociology from University of Wisconsin-Madison. Kathy Ingerson manager, granting programs Kathy Ingerson began working in the hospital’s Development Office in 2001 and has been with the Foundation since 2002. Ingerson manages the Foundation’s grants program, which provides $10 million annually to Abbott Northwestern Hospital and its surrounding community. Previously, Ingerson managed the Medical Education/CME departments of Children’s Hospital-Minneapolis. She has a bachelor's degree in human resources management and development from Metropolitan State University. Anne Walker Langaard director of development Anne Langaard joined the Foundation staff in 2009 and brings extensive fund raising experience to her position. Prior to joining the Foundation, she led the development department of the Minnesota Orchestra for five years, was vice president for development for Community Health Charities, and was director of corporate and foundation giving for the Orchestra from 1990 to 2000. Prior employers include Planned Parenthood, MEDA and ARC in Minnesota, and Aviva Center in Los Angeles. Langaard is a graduate of the University of Minnesota. Andrew McIlree senior development officer Andrew
joined the Foundation in February 2016 and brings with him more than 10 years

of experience in fundraising, strategic communication and project management. Prior to joining the Foundation, Andrew held fundraising positions in health care, higher education and social services. Andrew holds a master’s degree in organizational leadership from St. Catherine University and is a credentialed member Certified Fund Raising Executive (CFRE) International. He has an undergraduate degree in history from St. Norbert College. Laura Narhi donor relations associate Laura Narhi joined the Foundation in August 2015
and brings with her extensive experience in stewardship, annual giving, social
media management and event planning. Before joining the Foundation, Laura served the
University of Minnesota School of Dentistry as its Development and Alumni
Relations Coordinator and the Carlson School of Management as its Assistant
Director of Annual Giving. A native of Massachusetts, she holds a
bachelor’s degree from St. Olaf College and a master’s degree from the
University of Massachusetts, Amherst. Rachel Rivard clinical innovation research grants coordinator Rachel joined
the team in June of 2015 and serves as a liaison between the Foundation and the
Allina Department of Research Administration. Rachel’s background is in nursing with work
experience at Park Nicollet, Vascular Surgery, and Minnesota Gastroenterology. She holds master’s degrees in Nursing and Public
Health from the University of Minnesota and a bachelor’s degree from St. Olaf
College. Kirsten F. Yeager annual fund manager Kirsten F. Yeager joined the Foundation as Annual Fund Manager in February 2013 and brings with her more than 10 years of
experience in healthcare philanthropy and nonprofit fundraising. Prior roles include director of development for the
Lundstrum Center for the Performing Arts and manager of the Women’s Board at
the Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago. Originally from southern Indiana, Kirsten obtained her education at Indiana University, Bloomington. apikey = '3854eedad78f40c79297821a5a1c5e36'

heart attack Grief, gratitude and giving: A young family’s legacy Years of worry end in one ED visit Through scholarships, a nurse’s dedication lives on A cardiac wake-up call, and care that changed a life A new era for neuroscience care Remembering Virginia Piper and celebrating a milestone Rod and Barbara Burwell: Inspire others to give What Dr. Jason Reed really learned from biology Carol Huttner’s passion for advancing the nursing practice An enthusiastic supporter gives from the heart Dr. Abbott’s granddaughter's legacy In gratitude for a life saved Unique funding opportunity supports spiritual healing Retired nurse gives back to leave a legacy Golf with a purpose: Posing FORE Pink Countless acts of kindness help save a life Helping nurses achieve career goals Champion for breast care Hospital love story Medicine Ball About the Foundation Board of Directors Staff Publications Contact us Email us For medical professionals Physicians Nurses Research Transfers & admissions Medication protocols Enoxaparin Heparin (unfractionated) Heparin in pregnancy Current needs Advancing Excellence at Abbott Northwestern Hospital is raising funds for seven of the hospital’s centers of excellence. These are among Abbott Northwestern’s core services and, together, they serve thousands of patients and families every year. Cardiovascular Services - to support innovation and advance patient care with funding for the Health Care Delivery Innovation Center, rural heart health programs, technology, research and clinical education. Compassionate Care – to support the special health needs of vulnerable patients with funding for patient assistance, patient supplies, community access, patient education and patient-inspired research. LifeCourse™ – to support innovation in late life care with funding to influence best practices, provide training in other communities and expand the use of care guides. Mental Health and Addiction Services – to improve access to care and treatment for patients with mental health conditions and addictions with funding for crisis care in our Emergency Departments, psychiatric support in primary care clinics, and the Mother Baby Mental Health Program. Neuroscience Institute and Spine

column1: Institute – to support neuroscience patient care, research, innovation and education with funding for research and technological innovation, patient care and education. Nursing Excellence Initiative – to strengthen nursing practice for the future with funding for scholarships, nurse-led research and ongoing education. Piper Breast Center – to help strengthen prevention, treatment and support services for patients with breast cancer with funding for emergency assistance, renovations that contribute to a healing environment, innovative care practices and research. Virginia Piper Cancer Institute® – to help strengthen prevention and treatment services for patients with cancer with funding for innovative care practices, research and renovations that contribute to a healing environment. Where the Need is Greatest - Donors may make an unrestricted gift to be allocated by the Foundation based on the greatest priorities of the hospital and community. Courage Kenny Rehabilitation Institute receives gifts through a separate foundation. For more information, call 612-775-2589. 612-863-4126 Additional information Grateful Giving brochure Tax information Abbott Northwestern Hospital Foundation is a 501(c)(3) non-profit Type 1 supporting organization. The Foundation's tax identification number is 04-3643816. apikey = '3854eedad78f40c79297821a5a1c5e36'

column2: Home > Abbott Northwestern Hospital > Foundation > Giving stories > Retired nurse gives back to leave a legacy Abbott Northwestern Hospital Patient & visitor information Visiting us Patient preregistration Food & accommodations Send a gift Send an e-card Spiritual care Patient care concerns Preparing for surgery International patient services Interpreters Classes, events and support groups Services Find a provider About us Hospital overview Awards & ratings Frequently asked questions In the community Community Partnerships About Phillips Community Public safety Careers Career opportunities: job search Graduate nurse program Internal medicine residency program Pharmacy Residency Program Clinical Council Leadership team Volunteer Adult volunteer program Health Care Serve & Learn Experience Junior volunteers Weekly college program Newsroom Donate Give now Current needs Contact us Guide to giving Legacy gifts Tribute gifts Join a giving society Stories that inspire Mr. Erickson - heart attack Grief, gratitude and giving: A young family’s legacy Years of worry end in one ED visit Through scholarships, a nurse’s dedication lives on A cardiac wake-up call, and care that changed a life A new era for neuroscience care Remembering Virginia Piper and celebrating a milestone Rod and Barbara Burwell: Inspire others to give What Dr. Jason Reed really learned from biology Carol Huttner’s passion for advancing the nursing practice An enthusiastic supporter gives from the heart Dr. Abbott’s granddaughter's legacy In gratitude for a life saved Unique funding opportunity supports spiritual healing Retired nurse gives back to leave a legacy Golf with a purpose: Posing FORE Pink Countless acts of kindness help save a life Helping nurses achieve career goals Champion for breast care Hospital love story Medicine Ball About the Foundation Board of Directors Staff Publications Contact us Email us For medical professionals Physicians Nurses Research Transfers & admissions Medication protocols Enoxaparin Heparin (unfractionated) Heparin in pregnancy Retired nurse gives back to leave a legacy Sharon Mertz, RN, dedicated her entire 38-year career to Allina Health, with 25 years at Abbott Northwestern Hospital and 13 with Allina Health clinics. When she retired, she didn't stop giving back. ""Doctors and nurses retire for lots of reasons, but leaving patients isn't one of them,"" said Mertz, who is now a consultant at Abbott Northwestern. Mertz and retired doctor Jamie Gaviser co-founded a volunteer program that pairs retired nurses and doctors with hospitalized patients at Abbott Northwestern. These volunteers serve as a knowledgeable caring presence at the bedside. A graduate of Northwestern School of Nursing, Mertz also has made a provision in her will to leave a legacy gift to the Abbott Northwestern Hospital Foundation. ""Abbott Northwestern gave so much to me,"" explained Mertz. ""It was an important decision, and    an easy one, to give back."" ""Legacy gifts play a key role in Abbott Northwestern's future,"" said Richard Meyer, president of the Abbott Northwestern Hospital Foundation. ""Philanthropy is essential to the excellence in patient care that our patients and the community have come to expect."" Planned giving To learn more about planned and legacy gifts, contact Rich Meyer by email or at 612-863-4005 . Sharon Mertz, RN and retired doctor Jamie Gaviser apikey = '3854eedad78f40c79297821a5a1c5e36'

column1: Minnesota's most diverse communities: Phillips. Just south of
downtown Minneapolis, Phillips is home to nearly 20,000 residents
and is made up of four neighborhoods, including Phillips West,
Ventura Village, Midtown Phillips and Phillips East. According to
the 2000 Census, about 31 percent of Phillips residents are White,
29 percent are African American, 22 percent are Latino American, 12
percent are American Indian and 6 percent are Asian American. Phillips is one of the oldest communities in Minneapolis. One of
its main streets, Park Avenue, is known for its historic mansions
that were built by industrialists in the 1920s. Today, many of
those mansions have been renovated and are home to businesses and
non-profit agencies. Other organizations in the community include Allina Health,
Phillips Eye Institute, Wells Fargo Home Mortgage, Saint Mary's
College, Lutheran Social Services, the American Swedish Institute,
Children's Hospitals and Clinics - Minneapolis, and Andersen
School. The community's numerous specialty businesses such as
Ingebretsen's Scandinavian Gifts and Foods, Mercado Central, the
Heart of the Beast Puppet Theater and the Ancient Traders Market
reflect the its cultural diversity. Learn about community partnerships involving Abbott Northwestern. apikey = '3854eedad78f40c79297821a5a1c5e36'

Minneapolis Heart Institute® The Minneapolis Heart Institute® is recognized internationally as one of the world's leading providers of heart and vascular care. John Nasseff Neuroscience Institute John Nasseff Neuroscience Institute at Abbott Northwestern is the leading center for neurological care in the Twin Cities and Upper Midwest. Orthopaedic Institute Rated one of America's Best Hospitals by U.S. News & World Report in the specialty of orthopaedics, the Orthopaedic Institute provides an integrated, quality-care approach to the prevention, diagnosis, treatment and rehabilitation of orthopedic conditions. Penny George Institute for Health & Healing Provides integrative medicine, both for inpatients and at an outpatient clinic. Integrative/alternative medicine blends the best of conventional medicine with healing philosophies and a variety of healing therapies. Courage Kenny Rehabilitation Institute Courage Kenny Rehabilitation Institute offers comprehensive rehabilitative services for any short or long-term condition or disability. Spine Institute A Center of Excellence dedicated to the comprehensive management of spinal diseases and disorders. Surgical services Abbott Northwestern Hospital provides world-class medical and surgical services for many types of procedures. WomenCare® (includes Birth Center) The WomenCare® program at Abbott Northwestern recognizes and treats the special needs of women, from the child-bearing years through menopause. The program builds on the more than 100-year tradition of Abbott Northwestern Hospital in providing for the health care needs of women and their families. Virginia Piper Cancer Institute® The Virginia Piper Cancer Institute - Abbott Northwestern Hospital provides comprehensive care through all aspects of cancer prevention, early detection and treatment. apikey = '3854eedad78f40c79297821a5a1c5e36'

column2: Home > Abbott Northwestern Hospital > Services > Surgical services > After surgery Abbott Northwestern Hospital Services Surgical services Getting here Day of surgery After surgery Surgery checklist Information for family members of patients having surgery Laser services Frequently asked questions Photodynamic therapy TransOne After surgery After your surgery You are taken to the Post Anesthesia Care Unit (PACU) where a registered nurse cares for you as the effects of anesthesia or sedation wear off. Your nurse is at your bedside to help you. He or she will monitor you and treat pain or nausea, if present. You may not remember many of the events on the day of surgery due to the medications administered, but don't be alarmed if you experience this. Understanding and remembering all the information you need to know after being discharged from a hospital after surgery, delivery or illness can be confusing. MyChart provides online access once you get home to view the reason for your hospital visit. If you are going home on the day of your surgery Arrange for a responsible adult to be present at the hospital during your surgery and to take you home if you are discharged on the same day as your surgery. You will not be allowed to drive yourself. If you have not made these arrangements prior to your arrival your surgical procedure may be cancelled. When you go home, a family member or friend should stay        with you overnight. You stay in the hospital until you are awake and pain and nausea is adequately controlled. Your nurse goes over written home care instructions with you and the family member or friend who will be with you. It's important to have someone available to stay with you or to check on you the first 24 hours after your surgery. If you are being admitted to the hospital You remain in the Post Anesthesia Care Unit (PACU) until you are ready to go to your room. A staff member transports your belongings to your room. Family and friends are welcome to visit you in your hospital room. Your doctor writes orders for pain and nausea medication, which the nurses will administer. Talk to your nurse if you are experiencing pain or nausea. If you experience any problems, call your surgeon. Take care of your health online Use your secure Allina Health account to get better communication and faster answers online when it’s convenient for you: Read discharge instructions View test results and medications Manage clinic appointments Sign in or sign up now. apikey = '3854eedad78f40c79297821a5a1c5e36'

heart attack Grief, gratitude and giving: A young family’s legacy Years of worry end in one ED visit Through scholarships, a nurse’s dedication lives on A cardiac wake-up call, and care that changed a life A new era for neuroscience care Remembering Virginia Piper and celebrating a milestone Rod and Barbara Burwell: Inspire others to give What Dr. Jason Reed really learned from biology Carol Huttner’s passion for advancing the nursing practice An enthusiastic supporter gives from the heart Dr. Abbott’s granddaughter's legacy In gratitude for a life saved Unique funding opportunity supports spiritual healing Retired nurse gives back to leave a legacy Golf with a purpose: Posing FORE Pink Countless acts of kindness help save a life Helping nurses achieve career goals Champion for breast care Hospital love story Medicine Ball About the Foundation Board of Directors Staff Publications Contact us Email us For medical professionals Physicians Nurses Research Transfers & admissions Medication protocols Enoxaparin Heparin (unfractionated) Heparin in pregnancy Carol Huttner’s passion for advancing the nursing practice In May 2014, Carol Huttner, RN, BSN, MA, found a new way to share her passion for supporting nurses at Abbott Northwestern Hospital. As the former vice president for Patient Care and a current Foundation board member, she established a new giving society called Nursing Champions of Care . The new program is for current and past Abbott Northwestern nurses to support the Foundation’s Nursing Excellence fund. Dollars to this fund support nursing scholarships, attendance at conferences, and evidence-based practice and research fellowships to advance the nursing    practice. “Changes in health care mean that only the sickest of patients are hospitalized. In caring for patients who are sicker, nurses need to rely on the knowledge they gain through advanced education and other experiences. We need to ensure that our nurses are prepared    for the future,” said Huttner. Donations to the Nursing Excellence fund help ease the financial barriers that nurses can face in pursuing education. That frees them up to focus on exploring their ambitions, fulfilling their greatest potential and transforming the future of patient care. Huttner contends that advanced training and education for nurses leads to innovation in patient care and is directly related to a hospital achieving Magnet status . “This is what helps Abbott Northwestern maintain its cutting edge,” she said. Donate Give in support of nursing education by designating your gift to the ""Nursing Excellence Fund."" apikey = '3854eedad78f40c79297821a5a1c5e36'

column1: Slaton has had a lifelong connection to Abbott Northwestern Hospital may be an
connection to the hospital began before she was even born.  And now that
she has made a planned gift to the hospital, her legacy will last long into the
W. Abbott, MD, founded Abbott Hospital for Women in 1902, which later merged
with Northwestern Hospital to become Abbott Northwestern Hospital. Slaton was born at
Abbott Hospital in 1915 and was a frequent visitor throughout her childhood. “The
nurses were always glad to have me there because I was the well child,” she
still very young when her grandfather died in 1927, she remembers him as a
kind, gentle man. Her early exposure to hospitals helped shape her interests
and activities as an adult. She and her first husband, who was also a doctor,
helped establish a hospital in Texas. “I’ve always been mixed in with doctors
and hospitals,” she explained. Slaton knows that her
grandfather would be pleased to see how his hospital has continued serving the
community as he envisioned. She hopes others will be inspired to do as she has. By including Abbott
Northwestern Hospital Foundation in her estate plan, Slaton is both honoring a

proud legacy and creating her own. Planned giving To learn more about planned and legacy gifts, contact Rich Meyer by email or at 612-863-4005 . Amos Abbott, founder of Abbott Hospital for Women and Marie Slaton’s grandfather apikey = '3854eedad78f40c79297821a5a1c5e36'

As a participant, you will gain valuable experience by committing to volunteer at least six hours per week for a total of 72 hours in a semester.  In return, you receive the opportunity to meet with a professional such as a: physician nurse medical imaging technician physical therapist occupational therapist lab technician Space is very limited, so apply early. College student application Earn college credit It may be possible for volunteers participating in this program to earn college credit for this experience. It is each student's responsibility to coordinate all details with his/her college for college credit. column2: Home > Abbott Northwestern Hospital > Services > WomenCare® Abbott Northwestern Hospital Services WomenCare® Services Reproductive medicine Allina Health Home Health - Mother & Newborn Gynecology, urogynecology and female pelvic medicine services WomenCare® Caring for women Building on the more than 125-year tradition of caring for women and families, Abbott Northwestern's WomenCare® program offers care for a woman's lifelong health care needs. Abbott Northwestern has been serving the needs of women for more than 125 years, since the Northwestern Hospital for Women and Children opened in 1882 and Abbott Hospital for Women opened in 1902. Both hospitals were designed to provide care and support for    women's specific health care needs. Today, WomenCare® recognizes the unique needs of women, and provides a full range of programs and services to support and treat them. Abbott Northwestern Hospital is consistently voted as a Women-Friendly hospital in Minnesota Women's Press' annual rankings. Additionally, Minnesota Women's Press has recognized two of Abbott Northwestern's Centers of Excellence in its ""What Women Want! 2009"" issue -     The Penny George™ Institute for Health and Healing was chosen as a favorite clinic among female readers for alternative medicine and        The Virginia Piper Cancer Institute's Piper Breast Center was voted as a women-friendly hospital or clinic, and favorite place to get a mammogram and breast cancer information or treatment. Expecting a baby? The Mother Baby Center offers comprehensive services and programs, comfortable surroundings and the latest technology - all in a responsive, family-centered environment. .rellinks ul li {background-image:none !important

column2: Home > Abbott Northwestern Hospital > Services > John Nasseff Neuroscience Institute Abbott Northwestern Hospital Services John Nasseff Neuroscience Institute Neurosurgery Deep Brain Stimulation surgery Neurology Interventional neuroradiology Neuro-oncology Expert epilepsy care Intraoperative MRI Suite Skull Base Center Sleep Center Insomnia and Behavioral Sleep Medicine Program Sleep laboratory Stroke Program Support groups & screenings John Nasseff Neuroscience Institute The John Nasseff Neuroscience Institute at Abbott Northwestern is the leading center for neurological care in the Twin Cities and Upper Midwest. Each year, we perform more than 2,000 major neurological surgeries and 1,000 neuro interventional procedures.    We also treat patients for neurological conditions such as             stroke,             tumors of the brain and spinal cord, epilepsy, Alzheimer's disease, balance and movement disorders, headaches and sleep disorders. Advanced technology is combined with specialized physicians, skilled staff, dedicated facilities and focused programs to make John Nasseff Neuroscience Institute a comprehensive resource for neurological care and information. Recent technological enhancements include:             Intraoperative MRI Suite (iMRI) and             Varian Trilogy. Learn more about the accomplishments of the John Nasseff Neuroscience Institute: See U.S.News and World Report's ranking of Abbott Northwestern as one of America's Best Hospitals in neurology and neurosurgery Team approach At the John Nasseff Neuroscience Institute, the multidisciplinary staff of dedicated physicians, professional neuroscience nurses and skilled technical staff provide comprehensive neurological care for patients. Our team also includes physical therapists, occupational therapists and technical staff. Our doctors We

column1: have the largest concentration of board-certified neuroscience doctors in the
region. Find a neurologist or neurosurgeon Our nurses Our neuroscience nurses specialize in treating
patients with complex neurological and neurosurgical conditions. They recognize
that patients and their families require special care to cope with the
physical,  emotional, spiritual and social changes that may affect their lives.
Along with  quality care, our neuroscience nurses provide: technical   knowledge  and clinical expertise neurological
assessments care   planning  and discharge preparation education
for patients and   families. if(document.getElementById(8663) != null) {
unit is located on the  eighth  floor of Abbott Northwestern's Heart Hospital.
The unit was designed  with  input  from physicians, nurses, staff, families and
patients to create a  healing  environment around a patient-centered model of
care. This 46-bed  unit  offers patients and visitors the following
features: 46  private  rooms  designed to accommodate neuroscience
patient needs, including  ceiling  lifts and  state of the art beds epilepsy monitoring area that  is  designed and  equipped to meet the
specific needs of epilepsy patients and  their  families designated
space for Courage  Kenny Rehabilitation Institute therapies patient/family atrium with  a beautiful view, water feature, seating areas,
coffee maker and a computer   with  internet access patient/family
solarium with a fireplace,   beautiful  view, seating areas, coffee maker,
microwave, large refrigerator and   more TV/VCR/DVD, safe,
patient/family refrigerator and separate family   area in  each room Critical Care The John Nasseff   Neuroscience  Institute is also
home to a 12-bed Neuro Critical Care Unit   located on the  second floor of the
Piper Building. This unit features: continuous  EEG (brain wave)
monitoring at each bedside specialized   neurologic  monitoring
equipment family waiting room. if(document.getElementById(8662) != null) {

} Other clinical services Neurophysiological testing Our highly sophisticated neurodiagnostic testing is the best in the Twin Cities area. Some of the tests available are electroencephalography (EEG), electromyography (EMG), and evoked potentials (auditory, visual and somatosensory). if(document.getElementById(8661) != null) {

} Skull Base Center Abbott Northwestern's Skull Base Center is a multidisciplinary program dedicated to the management of skull base disease. Patients have access to the most current treatment options and expert neurosurgeons, otolaryngologists, neuro-otologists, craniofacial surgeons, neurophysiologists, neuro- and interventional radiologists and radiation therapists. The program also features a nurse coordinator to facilitate patient progress, provide close follow-up and bridge the gap between our team and referring physicians. if(document.getElementById(8660) != null) {

} Sleep Center Abbott Northwestern's Sleep Center offers comprehensive services for people who have difficulty remaining awake during the day, falling asleep at night, and/or staying asleep. Staff include board-certified sleep specialists, a psychologist, nurse clinicians and sleep laboratory technologists. if(document.getElementById(8659) != null) {

} Exceptional care. Excellent outcomes. John Nasseff Neuroscience Institute at Abbott Northwestern is the leading center for neurological care in the Twin Cities. Learn more. Abbott Northwestern Hospital recognized by Becker Hospital Review Becker's Hospital Review has named Abbott Northwestern Hospital to its list of 100 hospital and health systems with great neurosurgery and spine programs - 2016. Accreditation Program to monitor neurosurgical patients is first accredited in Minnesota Abbott Northwestern Hospital recently received accreditation from the Neurophysiologic Intraoperative Monitoring Laboratory Accreditation Board of ABRET (LAB-NIOM). It is one of 17 accredited programs in the U.S. and the only one in Minnesota. What you should know about concussions in sports A concussion is a blow to the head that affects how the brain works. Concussions can happen in free play, recreational sports, youth leagues, or in high school and college sports. ImPACT™ , a 20-minute computer test, would help your child in the event of a future concussion. column1: Hospital’s Emergency Department, she had begun to think that doctors would
never find the cause of her problem. Petersen has had Crohn’s disease for more than 30 years. For
2-1/2 years, she suffered inexplicable bleeding from her stoma, an opening in
the abdomen created as a way to bypass diseased portions of the intestine,
allowing waste material to be removed from the body. “I was getting weaker and weaker, and I wasn’t sure how long
I could survive like that. When I went to the hospital near my home, I was told
they couldn’t find the cause unless there was active bleeding. All they could
do was give me blood transfusions,” said Petersen. She received eight
transfusions over that period, and still had no idea what was wrong. In February 2015, she decided to go to Abbott Northwestern
instead. “Suddenly, I was surrounded by doctors. I just remember all of them
around my bed, discussing what to do next,” Petersen said. She had several
tests and returned home. The next morning she received a phone call that
brought her to tears. A gastroenterology specialist who had consulted on her case
the previous day had the answer she had been waiting for. “She told me they
knew exactly what was going on, and that it could be treated with surgery,”
said Petersen. “I was so relieved, I cried.” Since her surgery, she’s had no more problems with the
bleeding. “I can’t say enough about my doctors and the hospital. Everyone was
looking for answers, and they’re so kind and caring. It’s just a great
renovate the Emergency Department Our Emergency Department delivers life-saving care and
coordinates the critical first steps that help patients like Rosemary get the
care they need. Help us serve our growing community and its critical care needs
with a gift to the Emergency

heart attack Grief, gratitude and giving: A young family’s legacy Years of worry end in one ED visit Through scholarships, a nurse’s dedication lives on A cardiac wake-up call, and care that changed a life A new era for neuroscience care Remembering Virginia Piper and celebrating a milestone Rod and Barbara Burwell: Inspire others to give What Dr. Jason Reed really learned from biology Carol Huttner’s passion for advancing the nursing practice An enthusiastic supporter gives from the heart Dr. Abbott’s granddaughter's legacy In gratitude for a life saved Unique funding opportunity supports spiritual healing Retired nurse gives back to leave a legacy Golf with a purpose: Posing FORE Pink Countless acts of kindness help save a life Helping nurses achieve career goals Champion for breast care Hospital love story Medicine Ball About the Foundation Board of Directors Staff Publications Contact us Email us For medical professionals Physicians Nurses Research Transfers & admissions Medication protocols Enoxaparin Heparin (unfractionated) Heparin in pregnancy Through scholarships, a nurse’s dedication lives on Scott Becker lost his wife, Jane, to cancer decades ago,

column1: just as she was starting her career as a nurse at Abbott Northwestern. She had worked hard to become a nurse, and by all accounts, was
dedicated to her profession. That’s why, in the difficult months following her death,
Becker made a decision that helps others advance in the profession that Jane
loved. He established the Jane Wachtler Becker fund through the Abbott
Northwestern Hospital Foundation to provide scholarship funds for nurses to
continue their education. “It was the idea of trying to turn Jane’s illness and
passing into something positive and to honor her life,” said Becker. “We were
newly married and didn’t have much money, so it was a struggle to pay for
school. I think Jane would be happy to see other nurses benefiting from this
fund.” The Jane Wachtler Becker scholarships are announced each May
as part of the Nursing Excellence Awards given out during the National Nurses
Week celebration at Abbott Northwestern. More than 100 nurses have benefited
from the award since it was started in 1990. Over the years, Becker and other
generous donors have contributed approximately $100,000 to launch and sustain
the fund. Now, twenty-six years later, Becker is remarried and has
grown children, but he continues to attend the Nurses Week event each May.
“Every year, I’ll meet someone at the event who worked with Jane and will let
me know that they remember her,” he said. “It’s always meaningful to me.” Give today to support
nurses Donate to the Jane Wachtler Becker Nursing Fund or to the Nursing Excellence Fund to support
nursing research and professional development at Abbott Northwestern. For help
with your giving, please contact the Abbott Northwestern Hospital Foundation at
612-863-4126. Donate today Give today to support nurses. Give now Scott Becker apikey = '3854eedad78f40c79297821a5a1c5e36'

heart attack Grief, gratitude and giving: A young family’s legacy Years of worry end in one ED visit Through scholarships, a nurse’s dedication lives on A cardiac wake-up call, and care that changed a life A new era for neuroscience care Remembering Virginia Piper and celebrating a milestone Rod and Barbara Burwell: Inspire others to give What Dr. Jason Reed really learned from biology Carol Huttner’s passion for advancing the nursing practice An enthusiastic supporter gives from the heart Dr. Abbott’s granddaughter's legacy In gratitude for a life saved Unique funding opportunity supports spiritual healing Retired nurse gives back to leave a legacy Golf with a purpose: Posing FORE Pink Countless acts of kindness help save a life Helping nurses achieve career goals Champion for breast care Hospital love story Medicine Ball About the Foundation Board of Directors Staff Publications Contact us Email us For medical professionals Physicians Nurses Research Transfers & admissions Medication protocols Enoxaparin Heparin (unfractionated) Heparin in pregnancy Countless acts of kindness help save a life After a sudden attack of vertigo, Bill Manning knew in an instant that he was dying. He just didn’t know why. Unable to breathe, and with incredible pain in his chest, he insisted on being taken to Abbott Northwestern Hospital. Within minutes, he was being evaluated by Nick Johnson, MD, emergency medicine specialist. ""I kept speaking to Dr. Johnson… and I could tell he was listening deeply to me,"" recalled Manning. Johnson suspected an esophageal tear, a devastating condition that must be treated quickly. It allows stomach contents to spill into the chest cavity, resulting in significant pain and life-threatening infection. While nurses and others worked to stabilize his condition, imaging and lab studies were done that confirmed Johnson’s diagnosis. Emergency surgery was required to repair the 1-1/2 inch tear and clear the chest cavity. ""The many acts of love and kindness that I experienced are far too many to mention,"" said Manning, who has since chosen to make a legacy gift to the Abbott Northwestern Hospital Foundation as way of honoring the care he received. ""To be in the hospital and have someone wash your hair and pour warm water over your head when you are so sick is such an incredible act of love,"" he said. ""I was touched by – and I was cared for – over that 10-day period by 80 to 85 people. And that’s the reason I’m sitting here today."" Bill Manning shares his story. Donate Give now Designate your gift to ""Emergency Department/Critical Care Fund"" to renovate, enhance and expand Abbott Northwestern's Emergency Department . Planned Giving To learn more about planned and legacy gifts, contact Rich Meyer by email or at 612-863-4005 . apikey = '3854eedad78f40c79297821a5a1c5e36'

heart attack Grief, gratitude and giving: A young family’s legacy Years of worry end in one ED visit Through scholarships, a nurse’s dedication lives on A cardiac wake-up call, and care that changed a life A new era for neuroscience care Remembering Virginia Piper and celebrating a milestone Rod and Barbara Burwell: Inspire others to give What Dr. Jason Reed really learned from biology Carol Huttner’s passion for advancing the nursing practice An enthusiastic supporter gives from the heart Dr. Abbott’s granddaughter's legacy In gratitude for a life saved Unique funding opportunity supports spiritual healing Retired nurse gives back to leave a legacy Golf with a purpose: Posing FORE Pink Countless acts of kindness help save a life Helping nurses achieve career goals Champion for breast care Hospital love story Medicine Ball About the Foundation Board of Directors Staff Publications Contact us Email us For medical professionals Physicians Nurses Research Transfers & admissions Medication protocols Enoxaparin Heparin (unfractionated) Heparin in pregnancy Golf with a purpose: Posing FORE Pink After their mother was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2007, sisters Diana Witt and Emily Yund learned firsthand about the challenges of coping with a serious illness in the family. That made launching a fundraising effort in support of families served by the Piper Breast Center a natural step for them. “While insurance covers a good portion of the care, there are a lot of things that fall through the cracks,” said Witt. “We met so many women and families going through this. We wanted to make sure other families would have resources to help them.” It began with Posing for Pink. The two sisters orchestrated the annual production and sale of a calendar that featured many of their friends and family members, beautifully designed and tastefully photographed. Then they decided to expand their efforts and started the Posing FORE Pink Breast Cancer Golf Tournament. All proceeds are donated to Abbott Northwestern Hospital Foundation’s Breast Cancer Patient Emergency Assistance Fund. The event is held each June at Pebble Creek Golf Club in Becker, Minn. “When we started, we didn’t know anything about hosting a golf tournament
column3: we all just dove in,” explained Witt.  Members of their extended family also pitch in, and it’s added a new level of connectedness to an already close-knit family. “Being involved in something like this gives you a sense of purpose and something to be proud of,” she said. The Breast Cancer Patient Emergency Assistance Fund is designed to help families in need get help quickly, with a minimum of red tape. The Foundation is grateful to the many organizations that support the Emergency Assistance Fund and Piper Breast Center with generous donations throughout the year as a result of golf tournaments, music festivals and other special events. Donate Give today , and support breast cancer care and research at the Piper Breast Center. Diana Witt, at left, and Emily Yund, far right, with their mother, Sue Embry. apikey = '3854eedad78f40c79297821a5a1c5e36'

heart attack Grief, gratitude and giving: A young family’s legacy Years of worry end in one ED visit Through scholarships, a nurse’s dedication lives on A cardiac wake-up call, and care that changed a life A new era for neuroscience care Remembering Virginia Piper and celebrating a milestone Rod and Barbara Burwell: Inspire others to give What Dr. Jason Reed really learned from biology Carol Huttner’s passion for advancing the nursing practice An enthusiastic supporter gives from the heart Dr. Abbott’s granddaughter's legacy In gratitude for a life saved Unique funding opportunity supports spiritual healing Retired nurse gives back to leave a legacy Golf with a purpose: Posing FORE Pink Countless acts of kindness help save a life Helping nurses achieve career goals Champion for breast care Hospital love story Medicine Ball About the Foundation Board of Directors Staff Publications Contact us Email us For medical professionals Physicians Nurses Research Transfers & admissions Medication protocols Enoxaparin Heparin (unfractionated) Heparin in pregnancy More giving stories A story for the season: Dr. Bilka's final gift Paul Bilka, MD, made some decisions near the end of his life that will have a lasting impact on Abbott Northwestern Hospital. He made legacy gifts and a $1 million cash donation to the hospital. ""He looked at what was important to him, and that drove his decisions,"" said Abbott    Northwestern Hospital Foundation President Rich Meyer. Abbott Northwestern Hospital Foundation launches Critical Care Campaign Abbott Northwestern Hospital Foundation is raising $15 million from the community to renovate, enhance and expand Abbott Northwestern's Emergency Department in Minneapolis and Neurological Intensive Care Unit (Neuro-ICU). This campaign will benefit patients who need specialized care for conditions that are    life-threatening and require comprehensive care and constant monitoring. The McFarlands experience two strokes in one summer Joyce and Dick McFarland have given generously of their time, talents and resources to Abbott Northwestern Hospital for decades. So, when they each experienced a stroke, there was no question where they would go. They became patients of Abbott Northwestern's    Emergency Department and Neuro Intensive Care Unit. They share their story as the Abbott Northwestern Hospital Foundation launches the Critical Care Campaign to raise $15 million for these departments. George Family Foundation offers matching gift for integrative care Through the end of 2013, the George Family Foundation will match all new or increased gifts to the Penny George Institute for Health and Healing dollar-for-dollar up to $75,000. Gifts will support integrative health programs, such as the Transformative Nurse Training program. Two new arrivals - Liliana Hope's birth story When Denise and Adam Hauge learned they were expecting a baby last year, they were delighted to hear about another new arrival: The Mother Baby Center at Abbott Northwestern and Children's - Minneapolis. Denise delivered a healthy baby girl, Liliana Hope, at    the new center in March. Prescription Assistance Fund: A lifeline supported through philanthropy In 2012, the Abbott Northwestern Hospital Foundation granted more than $110,000 to three programs that assist patients who lack the financial ability and resources to pay for prescriptions. Etta and Elsie's Abbott Northwestern birth story It was an extraordinary year for Becky and Pete Slabiak and their twin girls, Etta and Elsie. In the fall of 2011, the girls made a dramatic entrance into the world. Just 31 weeks pregnant, Becky went into labor and had an emergency cesarean section at    Abbott Northwestern Hospital. Today, Etta and Elsie are ""beautiful, healthy and strong."" Paul Bilka, MD, makes a gift to benefit today's patients and tomorrow's physicians Paul Bilka, MD, found the perfect way to support his two passions of medicine and education through a planned gift to establish the Medicine Clinic Education Fund. Medicine Ball ""Baby Love!"" Chair Ashley Mehbod Ashley Mehbod has been connected to Abbott Northwestern since birth. She was delivered at the hospital, and when she and her husband started their family, they also chose to deliver at Abbott Northwestern. Mehbod gave back as chair of the 2012 Medicine    Ball ""Baby Love!"" gala. Employees and physicians support The Mother Baby Center It's not enough for some Abbott Northwestern physicians and employees to give of their time and talents at work. Many of them also have stepped up to make a donation to Abbott Northwestern Hospital Foundation's community giving campaign, physician giving    program or the 2012 Medicine Ball. apikey = '3854eedad78f40c79297821a5a1c5e36'

heart attack Grief, gratitude and giving: A young family’s legacy Years of worry end in one ED visit Through scholarships, a nurse’s dedication lives on A cardiac wake-up call, and care that changed a life A new era for neuroscience care Remembering Virginia Piper and celebrating a milestone Rod and Barbara Burwell: Inspire others to give What Dr. Jason Reed really learned from biology Carol Huttner’s passion for advancing the nursing practice An enthusiastic supporter gives from the heart Dr. Abbott’s granddaughter's legacy In gratitude for a life saved Unique funding opportunity supports spiritual healing Retired nurse gives back to leave a legacy Golf with a purpose: Posing FORE Pink Countless acts of kindness help save a life Helping nurses achieve career goals Champion for breast care Hospital love story Medicine Ball About the Foundation Board of Directors Staff Publications Contact us Email us For medical professionals Physicians Nurses Research Transfers & admissions Medication protocols Enoxaparin Heparin (unfractionated) Heparin in pregnancy One Call Abbott Northwestern Hospital's One Call service is available

column1: 24/7. The service enables referring providers to consult with Abbott
Northwestern specialists and ensures a streamlined process if a patient needs
to be transferred and admitted to Abbott Northwestern. Call 612-863-1000. Why One Call? We want patients to be able to recover in their local
hospital, so One Call allows referring providers to consult with an Abbott
Northwestern specialist to discuss care. If it is determined that the patient
must be transferred, the service will also get all patients - urgent or
non-urgent - transferred and admitted to Abbott Northwestern with just one

phone call. One Call provides consults for the following specialties: internal medicine hospitalist pediatric hospitalist critical care general surgery urology orthopedic surgery cardiology obstetrics other specialties as necessary Transfer Process One Call connects referring hospitals or physician offices
with an experienced transfer coordinator who will ensure your patient is
transferred or admitted quickly and efficiently. One Call staff will handle the complete transfer process
including: specialty physician consultation bed placement nurse-to-nurse communication patient transport (per referring hospital's
request) all other transfer needs Our goal is to ensure efficient continuity of care, keeping
you informed at every step, and creating an even more positive experience for
you and your patient. .rellinks ul li {background-image:none !important

column2: Home > Abbott Northwestern Hospital > Patient and visitor information > Spiritual care Abbott Northwestern Hospital Patient & visitor information Visiting us Patient preregistration Food & accommodations Send a gift Send an e-card Spiritual care Patient care concerns Preparing for surgery International patient services Interpreters Classes, events and support groups Services Find a provider About us Hospital overview Awards & ratings Frequently asked questions In the community Community Partnerships About Phillips Community Public safety Careers Career opportunities: job search Graduate nurse program Internal medicine residency program Pharmacy Residency Program Clinical Council Leadership team Volunteer Adult volunteer program Health Care Serve & Learn Experience Junior volunteers Weekly college program Newsroom Donate Give now Current needs Contact us Guide to giving Legacy gifts Tribute gifts Join a giving society Stories that inspire Mr. Erickson - heart attack Grief, gratitude and giving: A young family’s legacy Years of worry end in one ED visit Through scholarships, a nurse’s dedication lives on A cardiac wake-up call, and care that changed a life A new era for neuroscience care Remembering Virginia Piper and celebrating a milestone Rod and Barbara Burwell: Inspire others to give What Dr. Jason Reed really learned from biology Carol Huttner’s passion for advancing the nursing practice An enthusiastic supporter gives from the heart Dr. Abbott’s granddaughter's legacy In gratitude for a life saved Unique funding opportunity supports spiritual healing Retired nurse gives back to leave a legacy Golf with a purpose: Posing FORE Pink Countless acts of kindness help save a life Helping nurses achieve career goals Champion for breast care Hospital love story Medicine Ball About the Foundation Board of Directors Staff Publications Contact us Email us For medical professionals Physicians Nurses Research Transfers & admissions Medication protocols Enoxaparin Heparin (unfractionated) Heparin in pregnancy Spiritual care Our mission Rooted in theological integrity and sacred traditions, we minister to the human condition to foster individual and corporate healing, meaning and hope. Spiritual care is an important part of the healing environment at Abbott Northwestern Hospital. Chaplains, Catholic Priests, and a Jewish liaison are part of the health care team. Spiritual care staff are available to all patients and their loved ones. Our scope of practice Quality spiritual care: Responding to the deepest healing needs of patients and their loved ones through spiritual assessment, care and counseling in collaboration with health care staff. Clinical education for ministry: Developing competent, spiritually and ethically sensitive professionals in ministry, through the clinical education program. Leadership in ethics: Promoting values of a just and compassionate society with the hospital, health system and broader community. Services Chaplains respect all religious or spiritual preferences and collaborate with hospital staff to give patients the best care possible including: attending to the spiritual and emotional well-being of patients and their loved ones listening and assisting in making meaning of their health care experience providing spiritual guidance, devotions, rituals and sacraments offering compassion and counseling in the midst of injury, illness and frightening life changes contacting places of worship and clergy or other spiritual leaders consulting on ethical issues and health care decisions providing spiritual and emotional support for hospital staff Spiritual care staff Rev. Dr. Verlyn  Hemmen Rev.

column1: Dr. Verlyn Hemmen, M.Div, D.Min Metro Director, Spiritual
Care and Pastoral Education CPE Supervisor Allina Health Clinical
of the Allina Health Metro Hospitals Spiritual Care and Pastoral Education Department
and is a CPE supervisor at Abbott Northwestern Hospital. His undergraduate degree
is in psychology from Northwestern College in Orange City, Iowa. He has an M. Div.
and a D.Min. from Western Seminary in Holland, Michigan. He took his first unit
of Clinical Pastoral Education in Des Moines at Iowa Methodist and did his residency
at Pine Rest in Grand Rapids, Michigan. Ordained in the Reformed Church in America
since 1979, he has served three parishes over a 20-year time span: Twin Lakes Reformed
(Eagan, Minnesota). He began working at United Hospital in 2000 and offered the
first unit of CPE there during the summer of 2000. He is married and has a son and
} Rev. Paula Bidle Rev. Paula Bidle, M.Div Board Certified Chaplain, Association of Professional Chaplains Staff Chaplain, Abbott Northwestern Hospital Email

Neuro/Medical-Surgical Intensive Care.  She grew up in Ohio, and received
a BA  in Latin American Area Studies from the College of Wooster.
She completed the M.Div. at Chicago Theological Seminary and was ordained in 1986
in the United Church of Christ.  She served as a parish pastor on the northwest
side of Chicago, director of the interfaith Chicago Sanctuary Movement and missionary
in Chiapas, Mexico prior to moving to Minnesota.  She and her husband George

Chaplain Dunbar-Perkins 612-863-9665 Denise is a Staff Chaplain at Abbott-Northwestern Hospital
in the Oncology/ Medical/Surgical units. She grew in Chicago, Illinois and received
a B.A. in Biology at  University of Illinois at Springfield, a M.A.T.
from the University of St. Thomas and an M.Div. at United Theological Seminary of
the Twin Cities Area. She has been at Abbott since 2003, where she began her CPE
training as both an intern and a resident.  She is also a chaplain preceptor
for CPE students along with being an adjunct facilitator/teacher  for the
program. She has served  as chair of  the Sickle Cell Disease
Advocates of Minnesota (SCDAM)  and is an adjunct professor at United Theological
Seminary  teaching on Black church culture and Womanist theology.
She is an ordained minister of the Presbyterian Church (USA) and resides in St.
Paul, Minnesota with her husband and is stepmother of three adult children and three
Chaplain, Abbott Northwestern Hospital CPE Supervisor Allina Health Clinical Pastoral Education Email Chaplain
Goodman 612-863-4881 Kim is a CPE Supervisor, CPE Program Coordinator, and Staff Chaplain
at Abbott Northwestern Hospital in Minneapolis. She has her B.A. from Concordia
College, Moorhead and M.Div. from Luther Seminary in St. Paul. She did congregational
internship in an Anglican church in the suburbs of London, England, and completed
CPE residency at Abbott Northwestern. Kim is ordained in the Presbyterian Church,
(U.S.A.) and is active in the Presbytery of the Twin Cities Area. For the past eight
years she has served as a staff chaplain at United Hospital with a focus on oncology,
hospice and mental health. Kim lives in south Minneapolis with her husband and two
children where she is active in neighborhood revitalization, house restoration,
} Rev. Mark Mallinger Rev. Mark Mallinger, M.Div. Staff Chaplain, Abbott Northwestern Hospital CPE Supervisor Allina Health Clinical Pastoral Education Email
Chaplain Mallinger 612-863-4916 Mark is a chaplain and CPE supervisor serving Abbott Northwestern
Hospital in Minneapolis, MN. His undergraduate degree is in religious studies/youth
ministry from The College of St. Scholastica in Duluth MN, and he has a Master of
Divinity degree from Chicago Theological Seminary. Mark did his CPE residency at
The University of Chicago Medical Center and his supervisory training with Advocate
Health Care in Chicago. He served at various hospital and hospice venues in Chicago
before moving to the Twin Cities. Mark is an ordained minister with the United Church
of Christ and began his ministry at St. Francis Regional Medical Center in the fall

} Contact us To request a chaplain visit, Catholic priest or Jewish Rabbi, call 612-863-4370 . Chaplains are in the hospital on weekdays and on-call at all times. Urgent requests should be directed to a nurse who will contact the on-call chaplain.
